data.text: A tag or sheath, as of plastic, on the end of a lace, cord, or ribbon to facilitate its passing through eyelet holes.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: A similar device used for an ornament.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: A tag or metal sheathing of the end of a lace, or of the points (see <internalXref urlencoded="point">point</internalXref>) or ribbons generally used in the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries to fasten or tie dresses.
In botany, a pendent anther; also, a loose pendent catkin, as of the birch.
A tag of a lace or of the points, braids, or cords formerly used in dress. They were sometimes formed into small images.
data.attributionText: from the GNU version of the Collaborative International Dictionary of English.
from the GNU version of the Collaborative International Dictionary of English.
from Wiktionary, Creative Commons Attribution/Share-Alike License.

data.text: The cover at the tip of a <xref>shoelace</xref>, to prevent it from <xref>fraying</xref>.
data.attributionText: from Wiktionary, Creative Commons Attribution/Share-Alike License.
from Wiktionary, Creative Commons Attribution/Share-Alike License.

data.text: metal or plastic sheath over the end of a shoelace or ribbon
